results.title: Pedal power
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
A new look at the self-propelled bicycle, the most effective known way of translating energy into motion. Traces the development of the bicycle and examines the bicycle’s possible role in the modern transport scene in the light of the present world fuel crisis.

results.title: Finding Will
results.creator_credit: Kym Levett, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: As the keeper of historical artifacts for his family, Kym Levett recently visited the parts of France that were battlefields during the Great War. He took his two sons and his mission is to find the remains of his great, great Uncle Will Cundy who had died fighting during the war. This is a story of the journey to bring Private William Cundy home.

results.title: Cancer: the smoker's gamble
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
What does all the research which has been carried out in Britain and America in recent years add up to? This enquiry undertakes a detailed study of the latest scientific evidence and assesses meaning. Three establishments pursuing different lines of controversial research, are visited.

results.title: Dots and dashes
results.creator_credit: Jacob Romeril, Kevin Coughlin, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Catching mumps just before his 18th birthday prevented Kevin Coughlin from joining the RAAF during the second World War. But thanks to his connections, he was able to get work as a Wireless Telegraphist. In the end, Kevin ended up with skills that made him unique. Naturally left handed, he was forced to tap out morse code with his right hand. This afforded him a dexterity that meant he could do morse code with his right hand and write with his left which made him invaluable. He tells of his time in Darwin and, later, on Peron Island in the Timor Sea.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jacob Romeril, Kevin Coughlin, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Catching mumps just before his 18th birthday prevented Kevin Coughlin from joining the RAAF during the second World War. But thanks to his connections, he was able to get work as a Wireless Telegraphist. In the end, Kevin ended up with skills that made him unique. Naturally left handed, he was forced to tap out morse code with his right hand. This afforded him a dexterity that meant he could do morse code with his right hand and write with his left which made him invaluable. He tells of his time in Darwin and, later, on Peron Island in the Timor Sea.

results.title: Green machine (Plants)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Coverage of the life of a green plant. The work involved in the plant producing its own food is discussed as it the importance of this process to an overall understanding of ecology. Implications for the future with respect to harvesting energy and food with this process are also raised.

results.title: Encounter with Jupiter
results.creator_credit: Fisher Dilke and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
America’s National Aeronautics and Space Administration’s two robot spacecraft, Voyager 1 & 2 are making remarkable journeys en route through the solar system. Film taken by the two spacecraft are used to relay the findings on the planet Jupiter Edited by Simon Campbell-Jones and narrated by Martin Jarvis

results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”
Shows how strong government legislation has been largely responsible for the clean-up of Oregon’s rivers, roadside litter and air pollution problems.
Suitable for middle secondary level.

Suitable for middle secondary level.

results.title: If at first you don't succeed: you don't succeed [Colour version]
results.creator_credit: Peter Goodchild, Edward Goldwyn and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”
If a mother does badly in bringing up her child in the first 5 years of his life, then the child has almost no chance of success in school. Child psychologists can now measure a new-born baby’s capacity for solving complex problems and they have found that the infant’s motivation is the sheer joy of solving the problems, but if the potential is not developed the damage is irreversible. The results of this research are having major implications for education.

results.title: The Greenhouse effect (BBC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Burning fossil fuels such as coal, oil and gas adds more carbon dioxide to the atmosphere. This colourless, odourless, naturally occurring gas turns the atmosphere into a giant greenhouse, trapping more of the sun’s heat and raising the temperature each year. This informative documentary looks at the causes behind the greenhouse effect and the resulting possible changes in the earth’s environment.
